rev.comment: Do not delete templates that I did not add, it's vandalism. Do not delete fact tags until refs are added.
rev.diff:
Line 66: Line 66:
==Among animals==
==Among animals==
â
[[Image:Necromouse.jpg|thumb|A photograph showing a mouse apparently engaging in necrophilic activity.]]
+
{{Unreferenced|date=May 2007}}
â
Necrophilia is not unknown in animals, with a number of confirmed observations. [[Kees Moeliker]] allegedly made one of these observations while he was sitting in his office at the [[Natuurmuseum Rotterdam]], when he heard the distinctive thud of a bird hitting the glass facade of the building. Upon inspection, he discovered a drake mallard lying dead about two meters from the building. Next to the downed bird there was a second drake mallard standing close by. As he observed the odd couple, the living drake picked at the corpse of the dead one for a few minutes and then mounted the corpse and began [[Sexual Intercourse|copulating]] with it. The act of necrophilia lasted for about 75 minutes, in which time, according to Moeliker, the living drake took two short breaks before resuming with copulating behavior. Moeliker surmised that at the time of the collision with the window the two mallards were engaged in a common motif in [[duck]] behavior which is called [[Non-Human Animal Sexual Behavior|rape flight]]. "When one died the other one just went for it and didn't get any negative feedback -- well, didn't get any feedback," according to Moeliker. This is the first recorded case of necrophilia in the mallard duck- though not the only recorded case of [[homosexuality]] within the bird family.<ref name="MallardDuck">{{Cite web|url=http://education.guardian.co.uk/higher/research/story/0,9865,1432991,00.html|title=Necrophilia among ducks ruffles research feathers|accessdate=[[2007-06-17]]|publisher=Guardian Unlimited|year=2005|author=Donald MacLeod}}</ref>
+
{{original research}}
  +
[[Image:Necromouse.jpg|thumb|A photograph showing a mouse apparently engaging in necrophilic activity.]]
  +
Necrophilia is not unknown in animals{{Fact|date=June 2007}}, with a number of confirmed observations. [[Kees Moeliker]] allegedly made one of these observations while he was sitting in his office at the [[Natuurmuseum Rotterdam]]{{Fact|date=June 2007}}, when he heard the distinctive thud of a bird hitting the glass facade of the building. Upon inspection, he discovered a drake mallard lying dead about two meters from the building{{Fact|date=June 2007}}. Next to the downed bird there was a second drake mallard standing close by. As he observed the odd couple, the living drake picked at the corpse of the dead one for a few minutes and then mounted the corpse and began [[Sexual Intercourse|copulating]] with it{{Fact|date=June 2007}}. The act of necrophilia lasted for about 75 minutes, in which time, according to Moeliker, the living drake took two short breaks before resuming with copulating behavior. Moeliker surmised that at the time of the collision with the window the two mallards were engaged in a common motif in [[duck]] behavior which is called [[Non-Human Animal Sexual Behavior|rape flight]]{{Fact|date=June 2007}}. "When one died the other one just went for it and didn't get any negative feedback -- well, didn't get any feedback," according to Moeliker. This is the first recorded case of necrophilia in the mallard duck- though not the only recorded case of [[homosexuality]] within the bird family.
â
In the case of a [[praying mantis]], necrophilia could be said to be part of their methods of reproduction. The larger female will often decapitate or even eat her mate during copulation.
+
In the case of a [[praying mantis]], necrophilia could be said to be part of their methods of reproduction. The larger female will often decapitate or even eat her mate during copulation{{Fact|date=June 2007}}. However, since praying mantids have two or more brains within the whole of their bodies, with only one of these being in the head, the male could still be said to be alive even after decapitation, and so necrophilia may not be an entirely appropriate term in this case{{Fact|date=June 2007}}.
